holidays.name: National Gumbo Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the hearty and flavorful Louisiana stew known as gumbo, which combines meats, seafood, and the 'holy trinity' of vegetables in a savory broth.
holidays.origin: This unofficial food holiday honors a beloved Cajun and Creole dish that represents the melting pot of cultures in Louisiana cuisine.
holidays.funFact: Gumbo often includes okra or fil√© powder as a thickener, and the dish varies significantly across families and regions.

holidays.name: National Moment of Frustration Day
holidays.description: A quirky observance encouraging people to acknowledge and release their daily frustrations instead of bottling them up.
holidays.origin: Started in the 1980s as a humorous reminder to embrace our human emotions and take a breath during stressful times.
holidays.funFact: The day humorously suggests smashing a plate or yelling into a pillow‚Äîbut maybe not both!

holidays.name: Columbus Day (Alternative Observance: Indigenous Peoples‚Äô Day)
holidays.description: While Columbus Day commemorates Christopher Columbus's arrival in the Americas, many communities use this day to honor Indigenous cultures and histories instead.
holidays.origin: Columbus Day dates back to the late 18th century, but Indigenous Peoples‚Äô Day began as a movement in the late 20th century to recognize native resilience and contributions.
holidays.funFact: Some places replace Columbus Day with Indigenous Peoples‚Äô Day to focus on native rights and history rather than European colonization.

holidays.name: National Fossil Day
holidays.description: A celebration dedicated to raising awareness of fossils, paleontology, and Earth's prehistoric past.
holidays.origin: Established in 2010 by the National Park Service to educate the public about fossils' scientific and historic significance.
holidays.funFact: On National Fossil Day, museums and parks often host fossil digs and educational events open to all ages.
